notes: Sixth-generation Camry. Best-selling car in America. Available with I4 or V6. Manual transmission on base models. Reliable and practical. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Camry article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Prius. Popularized hybrid technology in mainstream market. Iconic aerodynamic shape. CVT transmission. Best-selling hybrid vehicle. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Prius article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation RAV4. Pioneered compact crossover segment. Available FWD or AWD. Manual transmission available. Practical and reliable. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota RAV4 article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Highlander. Three-row crossover SUV. Available with I4 or V6. Camry-based platform. Family-friendly vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Highlander article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation 4Runner. Body-on-frame construction. Available with V6 or V8. Manual transmission available. Off-road capability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota 4Runner article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Tacoma. Best-selling mid-size truck. Available in Access Cab or Double Cab. Manual transmission available. TRD off-road packages. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tacoma article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Tundra. Full-size pickup competing with domestic trucks. Available in Double Cab or CrewMax. TRD off-road packages. Maximum towing 10,400 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tundra article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Sequoia. Full-size SUV based on Tundra platform. Three-row seating for 8. V8-only powertrain. Towing capacity up to 6,500 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Sequoia article, January 2025 revision.

Retro-styled SUV inspired by FJ40 Land Cruiser. Body-on-frame construction. Available with manual transmission. Part-time 4WD with locking rear differential. Cult following. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota FJ Cruiser article, January 2025 revision.
